## Welcome to the Interdisciplinary Studies Module
In this simulated internship at Community 360, you'll apply interdisciplinary analysis to understand the complex issue of high school dropout rates in the community.
Working with supervisor Lianne Park and your intern teammates, you'll investigate causes, review research from multiple disciplines, and develop evidence-based recommendations.

## Library of Readings
Browse the research studies and resources relevant to understanding high school dropout. Click on each item to read the full text.
Vertical.Navigator:
- id: adhd_study name: Is ADHD a Risk Factor for High School Dropout? subtitle: Fried et al. (2016) - Psychology description: Examines ADHD as a risk factor for grade retention and dropout, controlling for IQ and learning disorders. ref: reading_adhd_study
- id: employment_study name: Is Adolescent Employment Still a Risk Factor for Dropout? subtitle: Staff et al. (2019) - Sociology/Economics description: Examines whether intensive work during high school increases dropout risk using 2009 longitudinal data. ref: reading_employment_study
- id: rural_urban_study name: Rural and Urban High School Dropout Rates subtitle: Jordan et al. (2012) - Education description: Compares dropout rates in rural vs urban areas, examining geographic and family factors. ref: reading_rural_urban_study
- id: marijuana_study name: Marijuana Use and High School Dropout subtitle: McCaffrey et al. (2010) - Health Economics description: Examines the relationship between marijuana use and dropout using propensity score methods. ref: reading_marijuana_study
- id: silent_epidemic name: The Silent Epidemic - Student Perspectives subtitle: Gates Foundation (2006) - Primary Source description: Focus group data and student survey providing direct perspectives from high school dropouts. ref: reading_silent_epidemic
- id: policy_brief name: Urgent Focus on High School Dropout Rates subtitle: Policy Brief - Education Policy description: Executive summary highlighting national dropout crisis and recommendations for intervention. ref: reading_policy_brief
